content.name: title_3
content.content:
The PIER App

Information for Patients, Carers and Health Professionals

content.name: html_1
content.content:
Introduction to the PIER App

Welcome to the PIER App. This app has been developed for Psychosis Intervention and Early Recovery (PIER) team to provide information for patients, carers and health professionals. The aim of the PIER service is to help people who have experienced their first episode of psychosis to recover, understand their experiences, manage any ongoing difficulties and minimise the chance of potential relapse.

This app alongside the psychoeducation given by the team, will help patients learn about their illness, treatment and prognosis with technology they already use on a daily basis. Â The PIER app aims to empower patients, carers, members of the public and healthcare professionals by sharing appropriate information, knowledge and support following diagnosis.

Project Team: Dr Debasis Das (Consultant Psychiatrist/Project Lead), Dr Shiraz Ahmed (Speciality Doctor in Early Interventions in Psychosis), Dr Neelofar Bargir (ST4 Registrar in Child and Adolescent Psychiatry), Dr Hanna Booth (Speciality Doctor in Early Interventions in Psychosis), Richard Kavanagh (Technical Delivery Manager LHIS), Gurtej Brar (Technical Services Manager), Ibrahim Pardiwala (Technical Support Specialist LHIS), Alice Brown (Product & Customer Support Officer), Gemma Clayton (Business & Marketing Manager)

content.content: Useful Infomation

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Information leaflets on Psychosis


  • Psychosis - Information for young people
  • Severe mental illness (Psychosis)
  • Psychosis - Information for parents, carers and anyone who works with young people
  • Information about Schizophrenia
  • Schizophrenia - Information for parents, carers and anyone who works with young people
  • Schizophrenia - Key facts

Information on Bipolar Disorder

  • Bipolar Disorder
  • Bipolar disorder: information for young people

Additional Links

  • Information and advice on mental health issues
  • Healthy lifestyle support and advice
  • Help with housing, crisis support and substance misuse
  • Choice and Medication
  • Care Cluster 10 Pathway information
  • Samaritans
  • Richmond Fellowship
  • LAMP - LAMP stands for Leicestershire Action for Mental Health Project. It is an independent charity based organisation for people and carers of people with mental health who are based in Leicester, Leicestershire and Rutland. They help to promote mental health and provide independent mental health advocacy (IMHA) to enable individuals to make informed decisions, Â convey their own beliefs and understand their rights.Please click on the following link for further details.

Glossary

Cognition: Relating to the ability to think, understand, plan and remember things.

Hereditary: When something is passed to you through your family line, for example, your hair colour.

Multifactorial: When many reasons can be behind something.

Organic: Relating to a physical cause. In mental health, this may mean the chemicals in the brain, or physical health problem that affects the mental health.

Psychosis: A clinical term which describes losing touch with reality.

Symptoms: Experiences that occur because of an illness being present. These can be physical or they can relate directly to the mind and emotions .

FAQ


1. Would I be stigmatised and labelled as being mentally unwell?
We work with people respectfully to help them to be as well as possible. We donât âlabelâ Â the people we see and instead focus on working with you towards recovery.

2. Will I have to take any medication?
We make decisions about medication on an individual basis

3. Can I stop taking my medication when I want to?
We recommend talking to your care co-ordinator or doctor before stopping medication to avoid becoming unwell.

4. Will I experience any side effects from Â any medication Iâm prescribed?
We tailor medications to suit your needs and will adjust them if you are struggling with side effects.

5. Will I be admitted into Hospital?
One of the aims of our team is to keep people well enough that they do not require hospital admission. We have lots of staff and resources to avoid this wherever possible.

6. Iâm worried Iâll be too much of a burden on the NHS and PIER service?
Not at all, we only see people who are suitable for our service, we Â have a fantastic team of friendly, Â dedicated professionals that will work closely with you on you path to recovery.

7. Can I not work out my problems from the internet and get help from there too?
The internet is a great tool for learning but doesnât replace meeting face to face with the PIER team. We understand people like to use the internet for information, which is why we created this app which contains useful information to help support you.

8. Wonât my friend know how to help me?
Friends and family are really important especially when we are unwell, however professionals who are trained and experienced can be very important to getting better.

9. Is it against my culture, or religion?
Getting better and staying well is a really important part of enjoying your culture and religion. We always respect cultural and religious beliefs and our team is made up of people from many different backgrounds.

10. Will I be in a mental health service all my life?
How long people are treated for varies from one person to the next. At Pier we usually help people for about three years, and only for whilst it is necessary.

11. Will my job will be effected?
Sometimes mental illness can affect your ability to work. Part of what we do at Pier is supporting people to stay in work, get back to work, or start work or education.

12. Am I to be separated from my family?
We believe positive family involvement can aid in recovery, our team supports families and will involve them in your care, as long as you are happy for this to happen.

13. Who else will find out?
We keep your records completely confidential: only professionals involved in your care will have access to these. Itâs up to you who you chose to tell.

14. Actually I donât think Iâm that unwell?
Sometimes the illness itself can trick you into thinking there is nothing wrong, but your friends and family will be concerned for you. Getting help can be a âleap of faithâ until you are well enough to have a better overview.

content.content: About

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Leicestershire Partnership NHS Trust

Leicestershire Partnership NHS Trust (LPT) provides mental health, learning disability and community health services for a population of more than a million people, mainly living in Leicester, Leicestershire and Rutland. The Trust employs approximately 5,400 staff. Find out more about our people and our work at www.leicspart.nhs.uk/

Follow us on Twitter @LPTnhs

Leicestershire Health Informatics Service (LHIS)

The NHS Leicestershire Health Informatics Service (LHIS) is a mature Information Management & Technology (IM&T) provider employing over 130 members of staff, supporting customer organisations across the UK with IT services and tailored IT solutions. Find out more about what LHIS can do for you at www.leics-his.nhs.uk.


Follow us on Twitter @LeicsHis



PIER Team

Contact Details for the PIER Team are:

PIER Team
St Peters Health Centre
Sparkenhoe Street
Leicester
LE2 0TA


You can contact us on (0116) 295 7060, alternatively you can fax us on (0116) 295 7061.
Please do not hesitate to get in touch with us if you do have any questions.

content.name: title_6
content.content: About Us

content.name: html_2
content.content:
PIER stands for Psychosis Intervention and Early Recovery

Our services are available to anyone aged between 14-64 years of age living within Leicester, Leicestershire and Rutland.

The primary aim of our service is to help identify those with a first episode of psychosis. We then intervene as soon as we can, and help manage & support individuals and their carers to aid an early recovery.

Our Team

We have a range of health professionals working within our team; Nurses, Occupational Therapists, Doctors, Psychologists and Support, Time and Recovery (STR) Workers. We all have different backgrounds, which helps us take a holistic approach to your care.

Early intervention aims to treat symptoms as early as possible, as the delay between the onset of psychotic symptoms and receiving treatment, (which is the duration of untreated psychosis (DUP) is considerable. The current mean average is between 1-2 years.

It is important to help reduce the length of time that symptoms are present for, as it has been found that the earlier the symptoms are treated the better the outcome. Long periods of untreated psychosis involve distress for both individuals and their families and can cause serious physical, social and legal harm. Young people can potentially also be a danger to themselves or others before receiving effective treatment, and the overall disability can develop aggressively within the first 3 years which is known as the âcritical periodâ. This can include: loss of education, employment, social networks, self-esteem and the development of persistent clinical symptoms, cognitive problems and co-morbidities.

If you have any symptoms, you can contact:

  • Your GP
  • Out of Hours(OOH)Services
  • Emergency Services

Some people may find that they prefer to ring Helpline Numbers. They are support services, whom will be able to offer telephone advice and support:

  • Richmond Fellowship
  • Samaritans

The most important step you can take is recognising that your experiences are new to you and seeking help early. Ask for a referral to the PIER Team, your GP can ring us or refer through their PRISM system.

content.content: Top

content.name: item_ea345a2e

• Home

content.name: title_6
content.content: What is Psychosis ?

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Psychosis is a medical term, which can include a variety of symptoms. These symptoms are unique to each individual, which involves having experiences, or beliefs which other people do not appear to share. This can entail losing touch with reality. Such symptoms can be a new experience, or it could have been present for a while but is now impacting on everyday functioning. Psychosis is not uncommon and is known to affect between 2 or 3 in 100 people throughout their lifetime.

The symptoms can vary depending on the individual. Generally they can include:
  • Unusual experiences, such as hearing, seeing or feeling things which you believe to be real but others do not share that same experience
  • Having unfamiliar beliefs which may feel genuine to you, but not others, and this belief is out of keeping with your cultural background
  • Certain thought processes could possibly be affected, such as:
    • Attention
    • Memory
    • Carrying out day to day tasks

There is no single cause for Psychosis, as it is believed that there is an interplay between a range of factors, which makes certain individuals vulnerable to developing symptoms of Psychosis, which can include:

Hereditary factors

Certain genes are said to play a role; if you have a relative affected this can increase your risk.

Organic factors

Increased levels of Dopamine, which is a naturally occurring neurotransmitter in the brain, can be found. It is not known what causes this increase; a range of factors are at play.

Emotional and Environmental factors
  • Possible complications at birth
  • Certain medical conditions
  • Trauma and stress
  • Illicit drug use

content.name: title_6
content.content: Referral Process

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Pre-assessment
  • Once referred, we will contact you and aim to invite you for an assessment within 2 weeks
  • If you are unable to attend this appointment, do let us know, so we can book you another appointment
  • It is always good if you can bring someone, to help support you and provide us with a more in-depth understanding of you
The Assessment
  • During your assessment, there will be 2 members of staff from the PIER Team present
  • This usually takes place at the team base, but a home visit can be arranged if needed
  • Questions are normally asked about your experiences, your lifestyle as well as relevant bits about your background to get to know and understand you
  • The assessment can last between 1-1 Â½ hours depending on how much information is required
  • There are times when a further appointment is needed to complete the assessment
  • During this assessment, you will be informed as to whether you meet the criteria for our service or whether there is another service best suited for you
  • On occasions, some individuals may need to be discussed at the multi-disciplinary team meeting (MDT) which occurs once a week, and you will then be contacted later
Accepted

We decide within a week of your assessment whether treatment with our team would be best for you.

Given a Diagnosis

Sometimes we have a good idea straight away about which mental health illness may be causing your symptoms. Other times there are a few potential causes, and it may take some time to be certain. This is nothing to worry about as we will tailor your treatment to suit your individual needs.

Allocated Care Coordinator

Your personal Care Coordinator will call you to let you know that you have been accepted for treatment with the PIER team. They will then arrange to see you as soon as it is convenient for you, to begin to get to know you and work out how best to help you.

Doctor (Psychiatrist)

Providing reviews, monitoring and prescribing medications when required. Your Care Coordinator will keep your doctor updated and seek advice, if needed.

Other Professionals

Depending on your need, this could include:

  • Psychologists
  • Occupational Therapists
  • Youth and Community Workers
  • Support, Time & Recovery Workers etc.

If during the assessment process you do not meet the criteria for our service and we feel another service would be beneficial for you, we will refer you to one or more of the alternative services, for example:

Primary Care
  • GP
  • Mental Health Facilitator
  • Psychological Therapy
Secondary Care
  • Community Mental Health Team
  • Forensic Services
  • Personality Disorder Services
  • Specialised Psychological Therapy

content.name: item_ea345a2e
content.content:
• Home

content.name: title_6
content.content: My Recovery

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Recovery

Recovery occurs when an individualâs health and well-being is restored back to itâs usual state, enabling you to get on with day to day functioning. However, it can mean different things to different people. Our aim is to help you think about what is normal for you and work towards this. Your Care Co-ordinator will help to guide you and your family towards the goals you set out to achieve.

There is no set time for how long it can take for someone to recover, as we are all unique and individual. It is important to be mindful that you may not get back to your normal self prior to becoming unwell, but we will be sure to try and get you as close to this as possible.

Recovery is not just about helping to treat your symptoms, but to also look at possible stressors around you which can impact on this so we can help to reduce and manage these. Treatment to help with this is not just about taking medications, as we also look into your physical health and well-being, talking therapies and social environment in order to help you in regaining a sense of self.

Diet

To keep healthy, we must also think about and work towards eating healthily. As what you eat can impact on your health long-term and how you feel. If you are on certain medications, such as anti-psychotic medications, which have been shown to increase your chances of developing certain conditions such as raised cholesterol, diabetes etc, eating the right foods can help you in the long-term. Below are some useful links to help you get started on thinking about eating healthier. You can also speak to a healthcare professional about this further.

  • Eating well and Mental Health
  • Useful Websites

Exercise

Exercise has been shown to be good for you, as doing exercise releases naturally occurring endorphins in our brain; the feel good hormone. This in turn would be beneficial for your mood and general health. There is a weekly gym group, please speak to your care co-ordinator for more details if you are interested in doing this or are wanting advice on how best to go about starting to exercise.

Sleep

Sleep is an important part of our ability to function on a day to day basis. Lack of sleep can impact on your mental health and general health in the long-term. People can have difficulty getting to sleep, staying asleep, or both. The first things we would ask is to see how good your sleep hygiene is, and discuss what things you can do to ensure you sleep well. Below is a website you can use to help with this. If you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to speak to your Care Coordinator or Doctor about this.

  • Sleep Hygiene

Routine

Keeping a daily routine is vital in ensuring that our body clock is in sync with the day. Not having a routine can impact on sleep, mental health and general well-being. It is important to be able to think about whether you have a routine and if not, to consider setting a routine up for yourself. It can be difficult to plan so you can always get the help of others to aid with this, including your care co-ordinator.

Relapse Signs

These signs are individual to you and occur when you start to become unwell and are important to try and recognise. It can be very informative to yourself and others as to how your mental health is. This is something that your Care co-ordinator will help you think through, it is a good way of you learning to understand yourself and being curious about the kinds of things which can act as stressors that could potentially trigger a relapse in your mental health. This could include a lack of sleep, using illicit substances etc.

Driving

Mental illness and medication can impair your driving. Please seek advice from your doctor or Care Coordinator. You will have to inform the DVLA that you are in contact with the PIER service for your illness.

content.name: title_6
content.content: Physical Health & Wellbeing

content.name: html_2
content.content:
When accepted by the team, you may require medications, such as:



  • Anti-psychotics (to reduce the psychotic symptoms)
  • Anti-depressants (to help with low mood)
  • Anxiolytics (to help with anxiety)

Medications can have long term effects on certain parts of the body, due to this, regular checks are done such as:



  • Checking blood pressure and heart rate
  • Blood tests
  • Heart tracing (ECG)

These checks occur at the start of treatment, then after 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months and yearly thereafter.

Introduction by Consultant Psychiatrist, Dr Debasis Das

Nerys Moeketsi (Senior Mental Health Practitioner), Care Coordinator

Clive Rudkin (Support Time & Recovery Worker), STR Worker

Sarah Perkins (Senior Care Coordinator), OT

Jon Crossley (Lead Clinical Psychologist), Psychologist

Psychiatrist Dr Neelofar Bargir, ST4 Specialty Registrar in Psychiatry

• Home

  • Contact

content.name: title_6
content.content: Patient Stories

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Breaking Through

1. An Expression

Recently I listened to a podcast which described mania or the hyper times quite well; âItâs like having your skin turned inside out, with all your nerves on the outside,â- For me I think this applies; when I was unwell I acted on impulse a lot, making some rash decisions I wouldn't typically agree with. This behaviour seemed crossed with such bad anxiety that I'd be having panic attacks several times a week, and viewing myself so negatively it was uncomfortable.

2. A Lighthouse

Thankfully, PIER really helped. Having that support system as I got better really complemented the transition from hospital back to everyday life well. Although I must admit that most of my recovery was a blur, I do remember that regularly seeing my PIER contact helped me to get back on top of things.

3. Normality

A few months after I got back into school and doing a-levels I started CBT, which allowed me to discuss things that I needed help making sense of, from a possible diagnosis and what that meant to how to improve my self-care. To stay well now, I try my best to do everything the doctor recommends. This means I try to go to the gym fairly often, I've taken up swimming and I often plan out my weeks to provide my life with more structure as this makes me feel more in control, which was especially useful during the busier periods of the school year.

4. Better than normal

There are a few life adjustments I've had to make because of this illness, like eating more healthy to combat the potential weight gain from tablets and making sure I go to bed on time to ensure good sleep hygiene. But to me it's a small price to pay in exchange for staying well.

5. Outreach

One of my problems before being hospitalised was constant anxiety and panic attacks, which I thought was completely normal. But thankfully I can now say I've not had a panic attack since being discharged. PIER were useful in cooperating with my school to rearrange my timetable so I could better transition back into school life at the start of the year and ever since.

6. Support

My PIER contacts were especially indispensable recently when I was finally given a diagnosis of bipolar. To say this diagnosis was heartbreaking is an understatement and so having CBT to talk about it in, and having words of reassurance from my main PIER mentor was immensely helpful in giving me hope for my future. Now going into my final year of a-levels, I'm incredibly grateful to be able to say that I'm applying to university, with a view to study Medicine. There is another side, and you do get past it.

A Testimonial

1. The Problem

When I became ill, I felt like there was something I should have done, but because I hadnât I was in serious trouble. I had anxiety, couldnât relax, and couldnât sleep even though I spent a lot of time in bed. I was confused and scared and paranoid, I also lost a lot of weight. I wouldnât take medication. I didnât like talking about it with the crisis team but as I did I got used to the idea of meds and getting better.

2. The Help

Talking to specialists within the PIER Team helped a lot. It was difficult to explain at first but with the help and support of my family and the PIER Team the nightmare started to disappear.

3. The Obstacles

Anxiety was my big struggle. I got a job and had to work with it, sleep with it and try and relax with it. After some months I decided to take medication and now it doesnât bother me.

Dreams Come True

1. Unfamiliar Returns

When I was back in England and met my family I thought that they were imposters and actually Thai people in the bodies of my family. I did not trust by family as a result. I didnât want them to cook for me, or drink anything they gave me and didnât want to leave the house. I also couldnât watch television because I thought the presenters on TV had a secret code that they were conveying to the world through the gestures they used and thought they were spreading messages specifically about me. Therefore, I thought there were a lot of conspiracies going on that directly involved me and this made me really scared and vulnerable.

2 .Getting the Help In

It was my family who contacted the GP as they were so worried and concerned about me because they had not seen me like this before and they didnât understand why I was behaving and thinking the way I was and ultimately they just wanted me to get better. It was a really stressful time for me but also for my family as well. The GPs assessed me and then sent round the Crisis team who decided that I needed to go to hospital on a section.

3. Inpatient Insights

I spent 4 weeks in a mental health hospital and learned a lot from the other service users who I was with. For example I realised that my behaviours such as anger and aggression due to the stress of my situation had a negative impact on others around me. I learned this because I saw another patient behave in this way and it affected everyone around them. I also couldnât understand why they were behaving like that and therefore realised that not everyone understands what is going on with me either unless I open up and talk.

4. Lucky Times

After 4 weeks of being an impatient I am very lucky to have met the PIER team who are a community early intervention psychosis team who were placed in charge of my care after I left the hospital and who have been integral to my recovery. Under the guidance of Community Psychiatric nurses, Occupational therapists, Psychologists and Psychiatrists I have made a successful recovery from my diagnosis of Paranoid Schizophrenia and am in complete remission at the minute. They looked after me through my hardest times and also my best and really saw my potential and empowered me to: understand my illness; look after myself and pursue my goal of becoming a mental health nurse. They really inspired me to do for others what they did for me.

5. Collaborative Constructions

I have had loads of side effects with various different medications such as weight gain, eye problems and hair loss so the Psychiatrist in the PIER team really helped me through giving me advice to find the right medication for me to limit my side effects and also maintain my health. All the while allowing me to be in control of what medication I wanted to be on and making recommendations based on my wishes. I have also had a few relapses but I have always recovered from them due to the right care and realise the importance of taking my medication every day. At present I do not have any symptoms of my condition.

6. More Support

The community psychiatric nurses and occupational therapists have been an ongoing support throughout my three years there and saw me regularly and created a great rapport with me. They monitored my health and we had an open dialog about my worries and concerns, how I was and they really listened to me and I knew that I could talk to them about anything.

7. Benefits of CBT

I have been helped to explore my issues through CBT with the Psychologist there and this has really helped me to challenge my thoughts and understand my condition. I have learned through identifying early warning signs or possible triggers you can successfully manage your condition and this is really important. So it is helpful to really understand when you are most at risk of having symptoms and also useful to be able to identify when the voices you hear, things you see or smell are real or not real. This is definitely one of the hardest things to do. I know that what helps me is in identifying patterns of these symptoms. So for example I used to think I was ugly so the voices I heard were always being negative about my appearance. I realised that these voices were only really coming from me because of the way I thought about myself. So if I hear them again I am likely to disregard them.

8. The Light is Here

I would say to other people who are having a hard time with their mental health at the moment or experiencing psychosis to know that things can and will get better even if you donât think it will at the moment, it will. With the right support such as psychological and medical intervention and the support from family and friends things can really change for the best. It is important to find the right care for you.

9. Disability?

I know there is a lot of stigma attached to those with Psychosis and talking about it can be hard but I was open and honest about my condition to my university interviewers and they did not see my disability but my ability. There will always be people who donât understand but there will also be people who do, like the PIER team.

10. Dreams Come True

I went back to University after my first psychotic episode and finished my degree and actually did surprisingly well and gained a 2:1 classification in Psychology BSc Hons in 2012 and now I am studying a PGdip Mental health Nursing course, as I was directly inspired by the team to do this, and will hopefully qualify in two years by 2016 so maybe one day I can also work in a Community mental health team!

11. PIER Feedback

The PIER team really showed so much compassion and care and empowered me to be where I am at today. I am forever indebted to them and I have had such a positive experience being one of their service users! Even during my transition from this team to a team in London they have kept me on the records until I settle in and they have been proactive in referring me to a team where I am studying. They have been great and really care about the welfare of their service users. I would highly recommend the PIER team and I will be calling up their âcomplaint phone lineâ in order to leave them a massive compliment and positive feedback!

A Journey of Achievements

1. Reflection

It hadnât always been that way. When I first became unwell I was having panic attacks. I was in a violent relationship at the time with a stressful job too. So my days were filled with worry, at first I blamed the panicked attacks on an ear infection causing dizziness. It wasnât clear to me at the time what anxiety might be, until I spent days in the house scared to go out, scared to watch the news, scared of everything. I always have a memory of sitting watching a hospital programme and someone had cut themselves on a knife, suddenly my thoughts were rushing, I was even scared of the knifes in the kitchen.

2. Trying to Cope

My thoughts would really run away with me, everything was centred on my anxiety, I spent days drawing to push out the thoughts, generally drawing cartoons and anything that wasnât deemed dangerous. I used to go to the GP weekly convinced there was something physically wrong with me to cause me to feel dizzy etc but she referred me to be assessed by a Mental Health Team. My determination kept me functioning to some degree, my mum would drive me to the local library where I would sit and look at art books and remember times when I didnât feel this way.

3. The Past

I didnât like going out as I constantly didnât feel quite in my body, itâs a feeling a donât have anymore and so itâs now hard to describe, but I remember how it made me feel, it made me feel that I couldnât go anywhere or do anything in case I wasnât really doing it.

4. Seeking Answers

I went to the mental health team assessment and explained my symptoms etc, but they discharged me back to the GP with information on anxiety and said I was perhaps getting better on my own. I think that if they had picked up some of the psychosis symptoms at this time then maybe I wouldnât have been hospitalised, but I took my information on anxiety and began to read...

5. Trying to get on with life

I started to work part time in a nursing home, which made me feel really good to help people, but for me I couldnât forget the people that died. Itâs a natural part of getting old but it only fuelled my fear of illnesses and death. And when my granddad died too it became unbearable. This is the point I started to become severely unwell. I wasnât sleeping well anyway perhaps waking every hour, but then thoughts of people dying at the nursing home filled my mind as I tried to sleep. I began to think of ghosts at night which made me feel too scared to sleep.

6. Things getting worse

At first I busied myself with books and games to distract me and avoiding all those fears. But then as I tried to work as well I was tired and emotional. I thought I was upsetting everyone, my concentration was low and I was rushing around trying to get things done at work, sweating. This was a Friday as I remember and so I had the weekend off. Over the weekend I continued not to sleep and by the third night of no sleep I began to become really distressed thinking a was dying myself, this of course wasnât true but I was convinced as I could even smell rotting. I began to hallucinate too, all I can remember now from that time at home is seeing people on TV changing from young to old in front of my eyes, and I remember thinking that this wasnât logical, but vision is a powerful thing and itâs hard not to believe something you see.

7. Time Out

After a period of five days with no sleep I was voluntarily admitted to hospital at the Brandon Unit. I was so desperate to be helped as not sleeping for so long was one of the hardest experiences of my life up until then. I felt so irritable and every single sound distracted me, even the ticking of a clock.

8. Initial Hospital Impressions

The first week I was admitted to hospital is quite patchy in my mind. I have memories that donât fit together and Iâm not sure what order they are in. But it was a combination of distress, happiness, and thankfulness all rolled into one. I didnât know where I was at first, in fact I thought I was in heaven, I thought everyone were ghosts and there were angels. During the first night I was in hospital I was extremely distressed and tried to get out of the ward as I was quite terrified of all these people roaming around in the dark, I was sectioned and secluded over night. I remember feeling that everyone was talking about me, not in a bad way but just in a joking kind of way. This felt both comforting and overwhelming for me.

9. Improvements

It was another two days before I slept properly. But when I did sleep for the first time I felt really good. I started to enjoy things again that I hadnât for almost a year before. I enjoyed drawing, clothes, going out for walks and seeing my family so much during this time. It was a very distressing time for my family too, they felt helpless.

10. Secure

During my hospital admittance I told doctors about my violent relationship and they acted quickly to protect me, banning all contact from my ex boyfriend. It is this that makes me glad I went into hospital, it really was, looking back, a pivotal moment for my life in a positive way.

11. Release and Recovery

After six weeks in hospital I was discharged and went back to my parents. It took months for my brain to recover physically. I can remember thinking Iâm never going to be able to concentrate on anything for more than ten minutes again. But thankfully the doctors were right and my concentration returned. I began to have flashbacks about my hospital admission, at first and thought that if I thought about it that it might happen again. But after seeing a psychologist for CBT these fears were addressed.

12. Resilience

CBT has worked really well for me. It was hard work but worth it as it has re trained my brain to think and address bad thought patterns. I use the techniques I learnt to this day. Slowly my confidence in not getting ill again grew, I began a University course which really gave me something to get excited about. I had also moved into my own flat in a supported housing which made me feel so much more independent, I could finally decorate my bedroom floor with scattered clothes and drink milk straight from the bottle!

13. Achievement

Iâm now coming to the end of my degree and looking to do a masters and PHD in the future too. And the really good thing that my experience has given me is to appreciate everything. I never thought I would live on my own or do a degree but with continued support from the MHT I have become the person I was before all this began. Iâve got anxiety by the short and curlies and Iâm not going to let it stop me doing what I want to do. With my CBT techniques my anxiety doesnât stand a chance and Iâve been doing Thai boxing classes at the gym just in case!

14. Words for the wise

I think if I was to give advice to anyone who has been through, or is going through what I have been through I would say; Take every piece of support that is available through the pier team, I have never been afraid to take all the support available and Iâve always followed my consultantâs advice on medication, these are factors that inevitably have made my recovery so successful.

15. Belief and hope

Also believe in yourself and never give up. There have been endless times that I thought I could relapse or that the anxiety was coming back but guess what it didnât happen. Thoughts are merely thoughts and itâs what we do with them that count. I would also say just try and push yourself slightly out of that comfort zone, I have done that a lot over the last three years and it really has got me where I am today. I hope that my journey inspires others to see that Mental illness doesnât have to be disabling, I have had what would be described as Severe Mental Illness and Iâm living a ânormalâ happy and successful life. I have been taken off my medication for the last 10 months and all is well. I think itâs quite important to exercise as this has also really improved my confidence. I still keep a diary as I find it not only therapeutic but it enables me to see how far Iâve come. I would also like to thank the PIER team and particularly Carmen, Claire and of course Dr Das for all their support throughout the last three years. Without such a specialised team available I may not have had such a smooth transition to wellbeing.

Different Realities

A year ago, June 2016, things were very different for me. I was sitting my GCSEâs and I was very keen to do very well to get into sixth form.

1. Different Times

I am usually quite a relaxed and chilled guy but I got obsessed with revising, without realising It, I got myself into a very stressed state. I began to get agitated and very upset in the exams and began to dread going into them. I did half my exams then I got too overwhelmed and had to stop. I felt I couldnât see properly or remember anything.

2. Different Realities

I was later diagnosed with psychosis, It worried me as well as people in my family. I donât remember much about my psychosis but I do remember some of the hallucinations at the time, they really scared me. I was hearing alarms, thinking the CIA were coming to get me. I was hearing helicopters and smelling smoke, this all seemed totally real to me, I even rang the fire brigade because I thought the house was on fire! I was just very emotional and not myself at all.

3. Getting There

My GP referred me to a psychiatrist, I was prescribed antipsychotic medicine. However, the first two types didnât suit me and made me incredibly drowsy and hungry, I had a bad reaction and couldnât tolerate the normal dose. The third medicine I was given had less side effects and my hallucinations started to go away.

4. Achievements

I was not well enough to go back to full time education In September, I gradually built up my time in school through the year. But here I am a year on and I am back to my more usual self. I have just sat four GCSE resits and I passed my maths GCSE in January.

5. Words of Hope

The most important thing to remember with psychosis is that it will pass. I know if you are a sufferer you might not believe this, but I hope this is of some comfort to family members, really this is only a temporary state of mind, but it is very scary when it happens.

6. The PIER Experience

Throughout my illness I have received the full support of the Pier Team, Daren and Stacey who visited me at home and talked to me about how things are going. They monitored me as I gradually reduced the dose of the medicine and came off it in November 2016. Some good things have come out of the whole experience I decided to get more physically active, I have joined a gym, started going to a boxing club to do training and I also joined an inclusive football team. I now also spend less time on social media. Itâs been a tough year but now I am looking forward to going to sixth form in September. Thanks to all the people that supported me through this.

content.name: title_6
content.content: About PIER

content.name: html_2
content.content:
This service is for people aged between 14-64 years, with a first presentation of psychotic symptoms who live within Leicester, Leicestershire and Rutland. We are based in central Leicester and receive referrals from GPs, wards and other health professionals.

The reason we have this service is due to research demonstrating that:

  • There is often a delay between the onset of psychotic symptoms and receiving treatment for it, with an average delay being between 1-2 years (McGorry and Jackson, 1999)
  • The longer this duration of untreated psychosis means the longer the individual and their family remain untreated and unsupported. As a result, there is further risk for serious physical, psychological and social harm (Lincoln and McGorry, 1999)

During the first 3 years of developing psychosis it has been found that problems develop within social or personal functioning. This period is referred to as âthe critical periodâ (Chatterjee and Liberman, 1999). The usual difficulties which develop during this âcritical periodâ include unemployment, deprived social networks, losing ones self esteem, and these tend to be more aggressive and have a disproportionately greater impact on later functioning (Birthwood et al, 1998).

In 2016 NICE produced âImplementing the Early Intervention in Psychosis Access and Waiting Time Standard: Guidanceâ, advising on best practice. See link below for further details of this:

  • EIP Guidance

content.name: html_9
content.content: Top

content.name: item_ea345a2e

content.name: title_6
content.content: Screening & Referral

content.name: html_2
content.content:
We aim to ensure that referring to us is as simple as possible, so our team is always happy to discuss a referral in order to clarify its appropriateness. If our service is not appropriate we will recommended an alternative. Below are a few bullet points, to help you think about whether the individual you want to refer is for our service:

  • Is there either evidence/strong suspicion of the onset of symptoms of first episode psychosis?
  • Are they aged between 16-64 years? (Those aged > 35 years will only be accepted for those first presenting since November 2016, as after this date the PIER Team was expanded to include this age group, but prior to this time the age group was between 14-35 years)
  • They have not received treatment for their symptoms and it does not exceed the previous 12 months? (Except for case transfers from other Early Intervention Teams)
  • They are not aged under 16 years? (Individuals under the age of 16 years should first be referred to CAMHS Services)

If the answer is âyesâ to all of these questions please be sure to refer to us. But if you do have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us.

The purpose of our team is to provide treatment during the âcritical phaseâ, i.e. the first 3 years. So if an individual has previously been discharged from the PIER Team, but are still within 3 years of their first presentation, re-referral may be appropriate. The MDT meeting will consider each case, bearing in mind how close to 3 years it will be since their first presentation.

Please be mindful that we are not an emergency service. If you feel that an individual needs to be seen urgently, please follow the usual protocol for this, which can entail referring to Crisis Resolution & Home Treatment Team, Mental Health Act Assessment, and Emergency Services.

content.name: title_6
content.content: Assessment Process

content.name: html_2
content.content: The PIER Team aim to commence and complete assessments within 2 weeks of receipt of the referral, however this can be subject to change depending on engagement from the service user. Above is a diagram demonstrating the assessment process.

content.name: html_9
content.content: Top

content.name: item_ea345a2e
content.content:
• Home
  • Useful Infomation
  • Terms/ Disclaimer
  • Contact

content.name: title_6
content.content: Engagement & Care Planning Process

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Once an individual is assessed and taken on by our team, our main aim is to be able to achieve a relationship with each individual, which incorporates a comprehensive assessment to enable us to engage well and plan care according to the individuals needs. The engagement and care planning process is explained further below.

Engagement

  • Each patient is allocated a Care Coordinator or Lead Professional (depending upon their CPA Status)
  • They will play a central role in engagement, assessment and the coordination of other workers to provide differing treatment strategies
  • Engagement by the key worker is seen as a positive intervention strategy in itself
  • Failure to fully engage in treatment and formal assessment does not automatically lead to case closure
  • Case closure due to lack of engagement would be as a result of the patient consistently refusing all contact with the service after every attempt to engage them has been made

Care Planning

  • Care plans describe the interventions proposed to address the needs identified during assessment
  • Take into account and be informed by existing care plans that may already be established by the referring agency/individual and will be entered on to the trusts Electronic Patient Record (EPR)
  • Our team will involve the patient in the development of their care plan and in line with the Care Programme Approach (CPA) policy, will provide the patient with a copy which they will be asked to sign.

content.content: Top

content.name: title_6
content.content: Treatment & Interventions

content.name: html_2
content.content:
There are a range of treatments and interventions on offer with the PIER Team, which is in line with the NICE guidance and the Access and Waiting Times Standards, these include:

  • Psycho-social
  • Family Work
  • Group Activities
  • Medications
    • Amisulpiride
    • Aripiprazole
    • Clozapine
    • Olanzapine
    • Quetiapine
    • Risperidone
    • Lurasidone
    • Chlorpromazine
    • Flupenthixol
    • Sulpiride
    • Zuclopenthixol
    • Olanzapine LAI
    • Aripiprazole LAI
    • Paliperidone Monthly LAI
    • Paliperidone 3 monthly LAI
    • Sodium Valproate
    • Carbamazepine
    • Lamotrigine
    • Lithium Carbonate

The National Audit of Schizophrenia (2014) has set out a clear set of standards in terms of the therapeutic interventions for those people with Schizophrenia. Please use the following link to view this:

  • National Audit of Schizophrenia

content.name: title_6
content.content: Discharge Process

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Treatment for patients will last for 3 years, depending on their individual need. Please be mindful that there may be circumstances when a patientâs needs would be more adequately met by a different service, so are not taken on for this period of time. For some people, they will not need any further specialist treatment and so their GP will be the main port of call after PIER treatment has ended.

When their time with the service is coming to almost 3 years, meetings will be scheduled with all professionals involved to do these 3 things:

  • Review Progress
  • Re-assess current needs
  • Discuss future needs

We aim to have frequent liaison and communication during this transition, to ensure a smooth handover of care. If you feel you need to discuss anything further please do not hesitate to contact us. If alternative secondary care is needed, joint working between agencies will help to facilitate the process of transfer. Occasionally, we keep service users on for a little longer than the three years to ensure that the most appropriate care is given to that individual.

If a Patient had been taken on and then discharged from our service prior to receiving a total of 3 years of treatment, and you feel that they are relapsing, you could contact us to discuss whether they could be routinely re-referred back to us.

content.name: item_ea345a2e

• Home
  • Useful Infomation
  • Terms/ Disclaimer
  • Contact

content.name: title_6
content.content: Readable Information

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Introduction by Dr Debasis Das (Consultant Psychiatrist/Project Lead)

Hi, Iâm Dr Debasis Das. I am a Consultant Psychiatrist and Project Lead for the App.

Psychiatrists are medically qualified physicians, who undergo further specialisation in Psychiatry. Their role in the PIER Team is in the assessment, diagnosis and management of psychosis, including prescribing medication.

PIER is a specialised, community-based early intervention in psychosis service, which supports people, between 14 and 64 years, experiencing their first episode of psychosis and who reside in Leicester, Leicestershire and Rutland, in the United Kingdom. We are a multidisciplinary team, consisting of psychiatrists, psychiatric nurses, occupational therapists, support time recovery workers, Youth & Community workers.Psychosis can be a very frightening experience, for patients and for significant others around them.

This app will give you information about psychosis and how the PIER team supports patients and their carers. Anybody can use this app, to get information on psychosis and its management.

I hope you will find the App useful. Please give us your feedback.

Care Coordinator Nerys Moeketsi (Senior Mental Health Practitioner)

Who am I and what do I do?

  • My name is Nerys Moeketsi and I am a Care Coordinator and Mental Health Practitioner.
  • I originally qualified as a Mental Health Practitioner
  • I have been a Mental Health Practitioner for the last 12 years
  • I work as a Care Coordinator within the PIER Team

All patients have their own Care Coordinator to organise and monitor the many types of help and treatment that we offer. The majority of contact that you receive with the PIER Team will be with your Care Coordinator. Your Care Coordinator will agree with you how often you will meet, and where. Initially this may be weekly but this may reduce as your needs change. They will work with you to enable you to think about what ârecoveryâ means for you. You will decide together what help you may need to work towards this. Care Coordinator works in partnership with both yourself and your family, who they will also support in helping you to work towards your unique recovery goals. Your Care Coordinator may also help with illness education, staying well and recovery planning, support with medication and referring to other professionals. Within our team, this might be psychologists or support time and recovery workers. Outside agencies include volunteering organisations or housing support. A key part of our role as a Care Coordinator is ensuring that your needs are communicated to the wider team, including your psychiatrist and helping to navigate your care through the wider mental health services.

STR Worker Clive Rudkin (Support Time & Recovery Worker)

Who am I and what do I do?

  • My name is Clive Rudkin and I am a Support Time and Recovery (STR) worker.
  • The objectives of a STR worker are wide ranging. STR workers in the PIER team aim to provide a high quality service in promoting the wellbeing of people currently under the care of the team.
  • The objective of recovery for a STR worker is to assist in the restoration of a good quality of life by helping to build a sense of Hope,Enjoyment, Control and Self pride.
  • The STR worker also plays an important role in promoting social inclusion. This form of support would assist clients in accessing appropriate resources such as suitable employment, education, housing and community support. The objective of promoting social inclusion would hopefully challenge stigma and discrimination.

How do I get to see a STR worker?

You would need a referral from your Care Coordinator. If you are already seeing us for one group of activities, you can request to do some other group or activities. This would then be approved with your Care Coordinator. Sometimes you may need an assessment so you can take part in certain types of groups.

Is STR work something that would help me at this time?

It is important that recovery from an episode of an illness is an integral part of a care plan. Enjoying a healthy lifestyle is vital in sustaining wellbeing. The STR worker can provide an important role in promoting a healthier body and mind. This can be achieved in many ways including groups and activities.

Our Qualifications

We have a different mix of skill sets and qualifications ranging from experience of working in treatment and recovery settings to youth workers.

Any Questions?

If you have any questions please feel free to ask your Care Coordinator who can either provide you with an answer or let us know of your question so that we can answer it for you.

What things do you offer?

We offer one to one work working on specific objectives for each client, in addition to this we also we offer the following groups within Leicester City centre;

  • Pool Group
  • Gym Group
  • Walking Group
  • Women's Group
  • Cooking Group

OT Sarah Perkins (Senior Care Coordinator)

Who am I and what do I do?

My name is Sarah Perkins and I am both a Care Coordinator and an Occupational Therapist. In my role as an Occupational Therapist, or OT, my role is specifically to help people achieve their goals in life in their different roles.

Psychosis can affect people in lots of different ways and affect how we live parts of our lives. For example you may have a job or be a student, your mental health may have made it difficult for you to continue with this aspect of your life. My job is to help you make decisions and support you to return to something that will work well for your life.

Other areas that I can help with are in relationships. For example, you may have very significant friendships, you may have a partner or you may be a parent. I help people to look at these relationships and support them. The role of an OT is wide and varied. If your Care Coordinator feels that you need particular help with these aspects they can refer you to myself or to one of my colleagues.

  • As an Occupational Therapist I assess and work to improve a personâs functioning as it may have been negatively affected by their illness. These may be things that you previously did but have become more difficult since becoming unwell.
  • Occupational Therapists may examine how your illness has affected your role such as being a mum/dad, a worker, student or a carer.
  • We focus on improving mental health by helping people achieve goals in their everyday life and examining their hopes and aspirations. This includes promoting independent living and doing the things that are meaningful to you.
  • There are numerous Occupational Therapists within the PIER Team. If your Care Coordinator feels you would benefit from an Occupational Therapy assessment they can arrange this. Care Coordinators within the team work together and perform many roles and may already be working with you to help with these.

Psychologist Jon Crossley (Lead Clinical Psychologist)

Who am I and what do I do?

My name is Dr Jon Crossley and I am a Clinical Psychologist. Within the PIER team there are three clinical psychologists, trainee and assistant psychologists and psychological therapists, we all offer psychological assessments, therapy and interventions.

Who are Clinical Psychologists and Psychological Therapists?

Clinical Psychologists

  • Studied psychology at university to get a degree and then a doctorate
  • Trained extensively in the NHS to become a clinical psychologist

Psychological Therapists

  • Trained as mental health nurses or occupational therapists in mental health
  • Completed further specialist training in psychological therapies

Is Psychological Therapy something that would help me?

All patients cared for by the PIER team are entitled to psychological therapy. Psychological therapies are a very important part of what we offer as a team. These can be on a one-on-one basis, in a group, or with your family. Whether you would like to have psychological therapy is an individual decision, made with yourself and your Care Coordinator or PIER team doctor. They may suggest it, or you can ask about it at any time. If you decide to go ahead, you will meet with a clinical psychologist or psychological therapist. During this assessment meeting you will discuss your difficulties and decide with them whether this type of treatment will help you.

Therapy is tailored to your individual needs

Therapy is used to help people understand their mental health difficulties. It involves learning strategies to reduce the experience of your symptoms, for example, hearing voices. It also teaches you ways of reducing their impact on your life. This way you can feel more in control and achieve more of your everyday goals. For many people, psychosis is not the only problem they are facing. Therapy can also help with lots of issues including anxiety, depression, recovering from trauma and managing emotions. Therapy is also used to help whole families support and understand one another better.

What Psychological Therapies do you offer?

In this team we use a range of therapies. These include but are not exclusively:

  • Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT)
  • CBTp (which is a specialist CBT for Psychosis)
  • Behavioural Family Therapy
  • Systemic Family Therapy

All of these therapies listed above (and also some which are used a little less often) have been developed over many years of experience and there is lots of evidence that they are helpful. Our Clinical Psychologists are highly trained to combine different types to help each person in the best way.

What Does Psychological Therapy involve?

  • An individual plan created between you and your Clinical Psychologist or Psychological Therapist
  • Regular meetings, lasting one hour, usually every week or every fortnight (if your treatment is as part of a group, this will run weekly for a set period of time)
  • Building a good relationship between you and the professional carrying out your therapy, and working together to help you overcome your difficulties
  • Practising techniques at home that you have learned in your sessions
  • Specialist Assessments: these are additional to your regular therapy, for example, to help identify problems with memory

Psychiatrist Dr Neelofar Bargir (ST4 Specialty Registrar in Psychiatry)

Hi my name is Dr Neely Bargir and I am a Doctor who specialises within Psychiatry. Your first point of contact with a doctor would generally be during your initial assessment as we would usually be present with another team member, to help with the assessment and diagnosis of your mental health condition. We would work in partnership with yourself and your Care Coordinator, to plan and manage things such as:

  • The prescribing of medications if needed. If medications are introduced, to help monitor their effectiveness and see whether you develop any side-effects and if so, to manage this accordingly
  • If required, we would also refer you to other specialties and services.
  • We do not just oversee your mental health but also your physical health and well-being, as we like to take on a holistic approach and work in conjunction with other members within our multi-disciplinary team to help manage and support you as best we can.
  • We help to assess and manage any emerging or chronic risks to yourself and others as we want to try and help contain these within the community and prevent these from escalating into possible hospital admission

But most importantly we are here for you, with the rest of our team, to help support and guide you in working towards the individual you aim to be.

content.name: title_47
content.content: Treatment and Interventions

content.name: html_2
content.content:
There are a range of treatments and interventions on offer with the PIER Team, which is in line with the NICE guidance and the Access and Waiting Times Standards, these include:

Medications

Most people experiencing psychosis will need to be treated with medication, and taking it the right way is an important part of getting better and staying well. Here we will look at the different types of medication that you may be offered.

Antipsychotics

These medications are used very commonly to help reduce or stop the unusual experiences that psychosis creates. In turn this can also help you to get back on your feet again, think more clearly and concentrate on day to day tasks. The dose used will vary from person to person. Sometimes people have to try more than one medication to find the one that suits them best.

Antipsychotic medications can be given as a tablet (or occasionally a liquid), but for some people injections work better. This can help with keeping the doses at the right level in the body and is very useful if you are forgetful with medicine. There are two main types of Antipsychotic, Newer (Atypical) and Older (Typical).

The newer antipsychotic medication includes:

  • Amisulpiride
  • Aripiprazole (also known as Abilify)
  • Clozapine (also known as Clozaril)
  • Olanzapine (also known as Zyprexa)
  • Quetiapine (also known as Seroquel)
  • Risperidone (also known as Risperdal)
  • Lurasidone

The older antipsychotic medication includes:

  • Chlorpromazine
  • Flupenthixol (also known as Depixol)
  • Sulpiride
  • Zuclopenthixol (also known as Clopixol)

Depot or Long Acting Injections (LAI)

As mentioned above, taking medication as an injection (sometimes called a depot) can be helpful to many people. The injections are given by community psychiatric nurses either at the team base or at your home. They are given every one to four weeks into the muscle either in the top of the arm or into the bottom. If you are switching from tablets to an injection, you may need to use both for a while. Your Doctor or Care Co-ordinator will advise you on this. If you are prescribed the Olanzapine injection then you will need to attend a clinic so that you can be monitored afterwards.

  • Olanzapine LAI
  • Aripiprazole LAI
  • Paliperidone Monthly LAI
  • Paliperidone 3 monthly LAI

Medication to stabilise mood (Mood Stabilisers)

These medications are used for people who have bipolar disorder, severe depression or hypomania; conditions which severely alter a personâs mood to the extent that it interferes with their daily life. Some people who are referred to the PIER Team have psychosis because they have bipolar disorder (formerly known as manic depression). If the reason for psychotic symptoms is because of bipolar disorder then your main medication may be a mood stabiliser. They can also be used alongside antipsychotic medication.

Some mood stabilisers are actually medicines used for the treatment of epilepsy, known as Anticonvulsants. All of these are effective treatments. They may cause nausea or dry mouth as side effects. They are:

  • Sodium Valproate (also known as Depakote or Epilim)
  • Carbamazepine (also known as Tegretol)
  • Lamotrigine (Also known as lamictal)

Another medication sometimes used is:

  • Lithium Carbonate (also known as Camcolit, Priadel or Li-Liquid)
  • Certain antipsychotics are also used as mood stabilisers, such as Quetiapine, Risperidone, Aripiprazole and Olanzapine.

Other Medications

At times other medications could also be used; these can include anti-depressants. Sometimes, people who experience psychosis also experience depression. This may occur specifically after an episode of psychosis or generally alongside psychotic illness. It can take up to two weeks to experience the benefit of an antidepressant, and as with antipsychotics, every person reacts differently to them. Hence it may be necessary to try more than one before settling on the one which is right for you. Side effects are often minimal or temporary, depending on the type of medicine. They always come in tablet form.

Psycho-social

All patients cared for by the PIER team are entitled to psychological therapy. Psychological therapies are a very important part of what we offer as a team.

These can be on a one-on-one basis, in a group, or with your family. Whether you would like to have psychological therapy is an individual decision, made with yourself and your Care Co-ordinator or PIER team doctor. If you decide to go ahead you will meet with a Clinical Psychologist or Psychological Therapist. During this assessment meeting you will discuss your difficulties and decide with them whether this type of treatment will help you.

Therapy

In this team we use a range of therapies these may include:

  • Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT)
  • CBTp (which is a specialist CBT for Psychosis)
  • Behavioural Family Therapy
  • Systemic Family Therapy

All of these therapies listed above have been developed over many years and there is evidence they are helpful in your recovery. Our Clinical Psychologists are highly trained to combine different types to help each person in the best way.

It is used to help people understand their mental health difficulties. It involves learning strategies to reduce the experience of your symptoms. It teaches you ways of reducing the impact on your life, so you can feel more in control and achieve more of your everyday goals.

For many people, psychosis is not the only problem they are facing. Therapy can also help with lots of issues including anxiety, depression, recovering from trauma and managing emotions.

An individual plan is created between you and your Clinical Psychologist or Psychological Therapist. You will have regular meetings lasting one hour, usually every week or every fortnight. If your treatment is as part of a group, this will run weekly for a set period of time. Building a good relationship between you and the professional carrying out your therapy is important, and we work together to help you overcome your difficulties. We also conduct specialist assessments in addition to your regular therapy, for example to help identify problems with memory.

Group Activities

We offer one-to-one work, working on specific objectives for each client. In addition to this we also we offer the following groups within Leicester City centre;

  • Pool Group
  • Gym Group
  • Walking Group
  • Women's Group
  • Cooking Group

Please feel free to discuss with your Care Co-ordinator or call the PIER Team office, if you are interested in attending any of the above groups.

content.name: title_50
content.content: Support for Carers

content.name: html_46
content.content:
People are referred to PIER when they are experiencing the first onset of a psychotic illness or crisis. That is almost invariably a confusing, frightening and distressing time, not merely for them, but those around them â family, friends, sometimes even work colleagues. In PIER we try, as much as we can, to provide support to everyone concerned.

A Family-Orientated Service

One of the fundamental principles of the PIER Early Psychosis service is that it should be âfamily orientated'. At its heart that stance represents a recognition that human beings are social animals. We all exist and interact within social groups, and our thoughts, feelings and actions are all organised by those experiences with others. Our lives affect others and are, in turn, affected by them.

If someone is struggling; whether in relation to physical illness, issues of mental health, academic challenge or difficulties at work; those struggles will impact on other people.

In the same way, how those people respond; what is said or not said, done or not done; can make a difference both to how the person feels then and there, and also to how those difficulties play out over time. It is important to recognise that those mutual influences are likely to be much more significant when the relationships between people are more important or the amount of time spent together is much greater.


Carers Support

Supporting families ,or carers, might be as simple as being provided with adequate information, being included in assessment processes, meetings and decision making with respect to treatment plans. At other times families might benefit from more personal and ongoing support. That might be about having the opportunity to talk about how things have been, to have a chance to verbalise their distress or their fears about the future.

Equally it might include guidance about healthy strategies or approaches to particular difficulties. It might even pick up on other, intersecting, difficulties within the family.


Delivering support

There are a number of ways in which the PIER Service can respond to families/carers who have been identified with needs.


  • The involved Care Coordinator might create some space to talk; on an ad-hoc basis or more formally.
  • Alternatively, they might suggest the involvement of one of the Family Therapists in the team â to provide a more structured and progressive course of family consultation.
  • In addition to those other opportunities, the PIER Service also offers group-based courses of âCarer Supportâ.

The PIER Carer Support Groups have been running for about 10 years. Over that time their structure and format have changed a number of times in response to feedback from participants.

The group is facilitated by a Consultant Family Therapist, Senior Care Coordinator, Consultant Psychiatrist and Senior Mental Health Practitioner.



Timings

  • Currently groups are run as a 6 session course, with participants encouraged to attend all 6.
  • The groups are on a Saturday morning from 10.00am to 12.30 pm and held at St Peters Health Centre.
  • The meetings used to run on consecutive weeks, but participants reported difficulties in setting aside the time in that way. They now tend to be spread out over a 3 month period.

What happens in the group?

Weekly meetings include:

  • Educational components
  • Time for group discussion
  • Opportunities to look at strategies for tackling specific problems

What are the meetings like?

  • The facilitators try to keep things very flexible and quite informal
  • Some meetings can be very emotional and thought provoking
  • At other times the atmosphere can be quite light-hearted


How can I benefit from the Group?

  • The opportunity to talk with other families in similar circumstances, to share experiences, has been repeatedly highlighted by participants as extremely beneficial, and is now regarded as a central component of the approach
  • The facilitators will try to encourage all those who attend to feel able to talk about the problems that they are experiencing, the distress that they have been through and the worries they have about the future
  • If someone doesnât feel ready or able to speak in a meeting, they wonât be put under pressure to do so


Who is the group for?

The group is open to anyone who is in a caring role for a person whose mental health support is provided by PIER. This group might be helpful for you if you are:-

  • Finding it difficult to make sense of what is happening
  • Are unsure how best to respond to or support the person who is unwell
  • Feel isolated with the difficulties your family is facing
  • Or just would like a chance to talk with someone about what is going on

In the past most of those who have attended these groups have been parents of someone who is struggling. At times, however, the groups have also supported grandparents, brothers and sisters, husbands, wives and other partners, and, occasionally, even friends.


Please note - We have found that family members find it harder to be open to talk in this group context when PIER patients are present â whether their own relative or someone elseâs. Patients are, consequently, not invited to this group.

<style>
   @import url('http://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Open+Sans:400,600,700');

   *, *:before, *:after {margin: 0; padding: 0; box-sizing: border-box;}
   body {background: #2F2556; color: #B9B5C7; font: 14px 'Open Sans', sans-serif;}

   h5 {padding: 100px 0; font-weight: 400; text-align: center;}
   p {margin: 0 0 20px; line-height: 1.5;}

   .main {margin: 0 auto; min-width: 320px; max-width: 800px;}
   .content {background: #fff; color: #373737;}
   .content > div {display: none; padding: 20px 25px 5px;}

   input {display: none;}
   label {display: inline-block; padding: 15px 25px; font-weight: 600; text-align: center;}
   label:hover {color: #fff; cursor: pointer;}
   input:checked + label {background: #ed5a6a; color: #fff;}

   #tab1:checked ~ .content #content1,
   #tab2:checked ~ .content #content2,
   #tab3:checked ~ .content #content3,
   #tab4:checked ~ .content #content4,
   #tab5:checked ~ .content #content5,
   #tab6:checked ~ .content #content6,
   #tab7:checked ~ .content #content7,
   #tab8:checked ~ .content #content8,
   #tab9:checked ~ .content #content9,
   #tab10:checked ~ .content #content10,
   #tab11:checked ~ .content #content11,
   #tab12:checked ~ .content #content12,
   #tab13:checked ~ .content #content13 {
     display: block;
   }

   @media screen and (max-width: 400px) { label {padding: 15px 10px;} }
</style>
